topic.name: Early Reading Foundations
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Early Reading Foundations in Language Arts & Humanities

objectives.objective_text: Identify root words within larger complex words.
Identify homophones (there/their/they're) correctly.
Identify the feelings of the characters.
Identify rhyming words in a simple poem or song.
Identify syllable breaks in multisyllabic spoken words.
Identify subtle sound shifts in dialects or accents.
Identify common digraphs (th, ch, sh) in written words.
Identify complex vowel teams (oa, ie, ough).
Identify the front and back of a book.
Identify basic punctuation marks (period, question mark).
Identify the parts of a book (title page, table of contents, index).
Recognize 'chunks' in words (like -ing or -and).
Recognize the 100 most common words instantly.
Recognize the 1,000 most common words instantly.
Recognize alliteration and assonance in spoken poetry.
Blend sounds to read simple words smoothly.
Read simple sentences fluently without stopping for every word.
Answer simple 'who' and 'what' questions about the story.
Match letters to their primary sounds (consonants and short vowels).
Decode simple CVC words (Consonant-Vowel-Consonant).
Defend the need for precise vocabulary over common words in academic writing.
Explain how listening builds vocabulary differently than reading.
Decode technical vocabulary in scientific or historical texts.
Segment a written word into its individual letters/sounds.
Read words with consonant blends (bl, st, tr).
Write the sounds heard in a word in the correct order.
Blend syllables to read longer compound words.
Segment words into roots and affixes.
Read words with complex endings (-tion, -ture, -ious).
Break down a long word to spell it correctly.
Explain the rules for syllable division in English.
Defend the importance of precise articulation in public speaking.
Sound out unknown words letter by letter.
Use picture clues to help identify a difficult word.
Self-correct when a decoded word doesn't make sense.
Use context clues to determine the meaning of a decoded word.
Decode words with multiple syllables quickly.
Explain the meaning of a word based on its parts.
Defend an interpretation of a text based on precise word definitions.
Read 'rule-breaker' words that can't be sounded out (said, was).
Spell common sight words correctly in writing.
Spell high-frequency words correctly in all written work.
Read fluent prose without hesitation on common words.
Explain the difference between sight recognition and phonetic decoding.
Sit quietly and listen to a story.
Predict what might happen next.
Summarize the main plot points of a chapter read aloud.
Explain the motivation of a character.
Ask clarifying questions about confusing parts.
Defend the oral tradition as a valid form of literature.
Isolate the first sound in a spoken word (e.g., /d/ in dog).
Blend spoken sounds together to make a word (/c/-/a/-/t/ -> cat).
Segment a spoken word into its individual sounds.
Manipulate sounds in words (e.g., change /s/ in 'slip' to /c/ -> 'clip').
Distinguish between similar vowel sounds (short e vs. short i).
Explain how phonemic awareness aids in spelling unfamiliar words.
Defend the importance of oral tradition in preserving language sounds.
Decode multisyllabic words using prefixes and suffixes.
Explain why some words break standard phonics rules.
Defend the logic behind English orthography despite its complexity.
Track text from left to right and top to bottom.
Distinguish between a letter, a word, and a sentence.
Explain the function of paragraphs and indentation.
Use bold or italicized text to find important information.
Explain how headings and subheadings organize information.
Defend the importance of standard formatting for clarity.
Connect segmentation skills to learning foreign vocabulary.
Analyze the phonemic structure of complex vocabulary words.
Apply decoding strategies to read unfamiliar academic vocabulary.
Analyze how prefixes change the meaning of a root word.
Interpret the structural components of academic terms.
Apply knowledge of cognates to understand new words.
Analyze the structure of a sentence to aid in decoding difficult terms.
Interpret words with Greek or Latin roots.
Connect decoding fluency to reading comprehension speed.
Analyze why certain words became high-frequency in English.
Interpret the usage of common academic transition words (however, therefore).
Connect sight word fluency to reading stamina.
Compare the read-aloud book with the movie version (if applicable).
Analyze the tone and voice of the narrator.
Interpret auditory cues (pause, emphasis) to understand meaning.
Connect the themes of the read-aloud to current events.
Connect sound patterns to the rhythm and meter of poetry.
Apply the 'silent e' rule to read long vowel words.
Analyze the etymology of words to explain their spelling.
Interpret the pronunciation key in a dictionary.
Connect phonics rules to the history of the English language.
Compare fiction and non-fiction text features.
Analyze the layout of a textbook or article.
Interpret footnotes, endnotes, and citations.
Connect the formatting of a text to its genre.
Evaluate the role of phonology in language evolution.
Evaluate the author's choice of complex vocabulary.
Evaluate the morphological structure of complex medical or legal terms.
Evaluate the impact of repetitive language in a text.
Evaluate the rhetorical effectiveness of a spoken speech.
Evaluate the effectiveness of different phonics instruction methods.
Evaluate the layout and design of a publication.
Synthesize decoding skills to read ancient or primary source documents.
Construct a sophisticated vocabulary beyond high-frequency words.
Synthesize a broad sight vocabulary to read at a collegiate speed.
Construct new words using established blending patterns (neologisms).
Synthesize blending skills to read fluent, expressive prose.
Construct a glossary of decoded technical terms for a research paper.
Construct a critique of an audiobook narrator's performance.
Synthesize auditory information with written notes.
Construct phonetic transcriptions of spoken words.
Synthesize phonemic knowledge to learn pronunciation in a foreign language.
Construct a linguistic explanation for irregular spellings.
Synthesize phonics knowledge to decode archaic or dialectal texts.
Construct a properly formatted academic paper (MLA/APA style).
Synthesize visual and textual elements in a document.
